case_name: Kishanchand Lunidasingh Bajaj (Hindu undivided family) v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 234 of 1965 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURJSIDCTION Civil Appeal No. 234 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 19, 1963 of the Mysore High Court in I.T.R.C. No. 6 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July. 19,1963 of the Mysore High Court in I. T. R. C. No. 6 of 1963.

facts.text: Kishanchand Bajaj and his seven sons formed a Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: The Hindu undivided family owned shares exceeding Rs. 91,000 in value in public limited companies.

facts.text: The family commenced business in money-lending and commission agents on May 16, 1956 in the name of Messrs. Mangoomal Kishanchand.

facts.text: On August 22, 1956 Shyam Sundar and Girdharlal, two of the sons of Kishanchand separated from the family, each receiving rupees two lakhs in lieu of his share.

facts.text: On August 23, 1956 a partnership was formed between Kishanchand representing the Hindu undivided family of himself and his five sons and Shyam Sundar and Girdharlal.

facts.text: Under the deed of partnership, Shyam Sundar and Girdharlal were each entitled to a seventh share and the remaining five-sevenths share was to belong to Kishanchand as karta of the Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: Under the deed of partner- ship, Shyam Sundar and Girdharlal were each entitled to a seventh share and the remaining five-sevenths share was to belong to Kishanchand

facts.text: Dividends received in respect of the shares were credited to the profit loss account of the firm.

facts.text: The order of the Income-tax Officer was confirmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: He held that the Hindu undivided family was the real and legal owner of the shares, and that the shares were at numbertime the property of the firm.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the dividend income from shares standing in the name of Kishanchand Lunidasingh Bajaj and acquired with the funds of the Hindu undivided family of which the said person was the karta was assessable in the hands of the assessee family?

issues.text: where one taxable entity is the registered holder of shares in a company and the real owner of the shares is another taxable entity, the registered shareholder alone is liable to be assessed to tax in respect of the dividend from those shares

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal it was urged that where one taxable entity is the registered holder of shares in a companypany and the real owner of the shares is another taxable entity, the registered shareholder alone is liable to be assessed to tax in respect of the dividend from those shares, and therefore Kishanchand alone was liable to be taxed in respect of the dividend income from the phares,

issues.text: whether sub-section (2) of section 16 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 operates as an exemption from the pale of sections 3 or 4 or provides that liability to tax on dividend arises only when the person by whom dividend is received from the company is the real owner of the shares

anchor.surface_text: But sub-s.  2  of S. 16 does number operate as an exemption from the pale of either S. 3 or s. 4  1  of the Act number does it provide that liability to tax arises only when the person by whom dividend is received from the companypany is the real owner ,of the shares.

arguments.claim: dividend income would be chargeable to income-tax under the Act in the hands of the person to whom it accrues or by whom it is received

anchor.surface_text: Tax being charged by s 3 upon dividend income and not being excluded under s.4 such income would be chargeable to income-tax under the Act in, the hands of the person to whom it accrues or by whom it is received.

arguments.claim: the dividend distributed by the company would for the purpose of tax be deemed to accrue or arise to the real owner of the shares

anchor.surface_text: A company for its purposes does not recognize any trust or equitable ownership in shares it merely recognises the registered shareholder as the owner and pays the dividend to that shareholder. But the shares may, because of a trust or other fiduciary relationship, belong to a person other than the registered shareholder, and the dividend distributed by the company would for the purpose of tax be deemed to accrue or rise to the real owner of the shares.

anchor.surface_text: But sub-s.  2  of S. 16 does not operate as an exemption from the pale of either S. 3 or s. 4  1  of the Act nor does it provide that liability to tax arises only when the person by whom dividend is received from the company is the real owner ,of the shares.

holdings.text: The dividend income from shares standing in the name of Kishanchand, acquired with HUF funds, is assessable in the hands of the assessee HUF as the real owner.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in support of this contention was placed upon s. 16  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, and certain observations made by this Court in the judgment in Howrah Trading Company Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central, Calcutta.  1  In our judgment the contention is wholly without substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects petitioner's contention that only registered holder liable; applies ss.3 & 4 to charge tax on real owner's total income including dividends received on their behalf; distinguishes company registration from tax accrual.

holdings.text: Dividend income is chargeable under ss.3 and 4 in the hands of the person to whom it accrues or by whom it is received, and for tax purposes deemed to accrue to the real owner despite registration in another's name.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3, total income of the previous year of every individual, Hindu undivided family, company and local authority, and of every firm and other association of persons or the partners of the firm or the members of the association individually is charged to tax. By s.4 the total income of any previous year of any person includes... Tax being charged by s 3 upon dividend income... would be chargeable... in the hands of the person to whom it accrues or by whom it is received. A company... dividend distributed by the company would for the purpose of tax be deemed to accrue or arise to the real owner of the shares.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.3 charges tax on total income of every assessee; s.4 includes all income received by or on behalf of the person; company recognizes only registered holder but tax looks to beneficial ownership via trust/fiduciary relation.

holdings.text: Section 16(2) does not operate as an exemption from ss.3 or 4(1), nor limit tax liability on dividends only to the real owner receiving from company; it only deems year of inclusion and permits grossing up if registered holder is real owner.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of inclusion in the total income of an assessee.any dividend shall be deemed to be income of the previous year in which it is paid... But sub-s.  2  of S. 16 does number operate as an exemption from the pale of either S. 3 or s. 4  1  of the Act number does it provide that liability to tax arises only when the person by whom dividend is received from the company is the real owner ,of the shares.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.16(2) is processing clause for timing of inclusion and grossing up; dividend still taxed under ss.3/4 in real owner's hands even without gross up if benamidar holds registration; prevents double taxation.

holdings.text: Section 18(5) does not limit dividend tax liability to registered shareholder; credit for tax deducted at source given to person from whose income deducted, corollary to s.16(2) grossing up.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  5  of s. 18 also does number lead to that result. The clause provides that deduction made by a company and paid to the account of tie Central Government in accordance with the provisions of S. 18 and any sum by which a dividend has been increased under sub-s.  2  of s. 16 shall be treated as payment of income-tax or super-tax on behalf of the person from whose income the deduction was made, and credit shall be given to him therefore.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18(5) deals with tax credit for grossed-up dividend; does not define taxability of dividend itself, which falls under ss.3/4.

holdings.text: Dividend income is taxed in hands of real owner even if shares not registered in their name; Howrah Trading Co. held only that unregistered equitable owner cannot gross up or claim s.18(5) credit, but dividend was included in real owner's income.

anchor.surface_text: In Howrah Trading Companys case  1  it was held that a person who had purchased shares... is number a shareholder... within s.18(5)... The dividend income was included in the total income of the person who was the real owner of the shares... He did number say that the real owner of shares cannot be taxed in respect of dividend received by him, if the shares are registered in the name of another person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Howrah as limited to grossing up/credit under ss.16(2)/18(5); taxability of dividend itself under ss.3/4 unaffected; real owner taxed without gross up.

holdings.text: Under s.23A, 'shareholder' means only the registered shareholder, not equitable owner; deemed fictional dividend assessed to registered holders.

anchor.surface_text: It was held that the expression shareholder in S. 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act meant the shareholder registered in the books of the company. Therefore the amount appropriate to the shares had to be included in the income of the members of the family in whose names the shares stood in the register of the company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.23A creates fictional deemed dividend from undistributed profits; express terms limit to registered shareholders per Shakuntala case; distinguishes from actual dividends under s.16(2).

holdings.text: HUF liable to tax on dividend income despite no grossing up or tax credit, as no provision exempts real owner when shares registered in another's name.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument of counsel for the ap- pellants that because the dividend income in respect of the shares. cannot be grossed up, and credit for tax paid cannot be obtained by the appellants, the appellants are number liable to be taxed in respect of dividend received by them. There is, numberprovision in the Act which, supports this plea, and the scheme of the Act lends numbercountenance to an expedient which may lead to gross evasion of tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects extension of grossing up limitation to taxability itself; ss.3/4 mandate taxation of real owner's income; prevents evasion.

precedents.cited_proposition: a person who had purchased shares in a company under a blank transfer and in whose name the shares had not been registered in the books of the company is not a shareholder in respect of such shares within the meaning of s. 18(5) notwithstanding his equitable right to receive dividend and is not entitled to gross up the dividend under s. 16(2)

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City II v Shakuntala and others  3 does number support any different rule. That was a case in which a Hindu undivided family held certain, shares in a companypany in the names of different members of the family.

precedents.cited_proposition: shareholder in s. 23A means the registered shareholder in the books of the company

anchor.surface_text: Howrah Trading Companys case  2  The words of section 18 5  must accordingly be read in the light in which the word shareholder has been used in the subsequent sections, and read in that manner, the present assesses, numberwithstanding the equitable right to the dividend, was number entitled to be regarded as a shareholder for the purpose of section 18 5  of the Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: benefit [of grossing up] can only go to the person who, both in law and in equity, is to be regarded as the owner of the shares and between whom and the company exists the bond of membership

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3, total income of the previous year of every individual, Hindu undivided family, company and local authority, and of every firm and other association of persons or the partners of the firm or the members of the association individually is charged to tax. By s.4 the total income of any previous year of any person includes... Tax being charged by s 3 upon dividend income... would be chargeable... in the hands of the person to whom it accrues or by whom it is received. A company... dividend distributed by the company would for the purpose of tax be deemed to accrue or arise to the real owner of the shares.

Under s. 3, total income of the previous year of every individual, Hindu undivided family, company and local authority, and of every firm and other association of persons or the partners of the firm or the members of the association individually is charged to tax. By s.4 the total income of any previous year of any person includes... Tax being charged by s 3 upon dividend income... would be chargeable... in the hands of the person to whom it accrues or by whom it is received. A company... dividend distributed by the company would for the purpose of tax be deemed to accrue or arise to the real owner of the shares.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  5  of s. 18 also does number lead to that result. The clause provides that deduction made by a company and paid to the account of tie Central Government in accordance with the provisions of S. 18 and any sum by which a dividend has been increased under sub-s.  2  of s. 16 shall be treated as payment of income-tax or super-tax on behalf of the person from whose income the deduction was made, and credit shall be given to him therefore.

Sub-section  5  of s. 18 also does number lead to that result. The clause provides that deduction made by a company and paid to the account of tie Central Government in accordance with the provisions of S. 18 and any sum by which a dividend has been increased under sub-s.  2  of s. 16 shall be treated as payment of income-tax or super-tax on behalf of the person from whose income the deduction was made, and credit shall be given to him therefore.

anchor.surface_text: In Howrah Trading Companys case  1  it was held that a person who had purchased shares... is number a shareholder... within s.18(5)... anchor.surface_text: It was held that the expression shareholder in S. 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act meant the shareholder registered in the books of the company. Therefore the amount appropriate to the shares had to be included in the income of the members of the family in whose names the shares stood in the register of the company.

It was held that the expression shareholder in S. 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act meant the shareholder registered in the books of the company. Therefore the amount appropriate to the shares had to be included in the income of the members of the family in whose names the shares stood in the register of the company.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument of counsel for the ap- pellants that because the dividend income in respect of the shares. cannot be grossed up, and credit for tax paid cannot be obtained by the appellants, the appellants are number liable to be taxed in respect of dividend received by them. There is, numberprovision in the Act which, supports this plea, and the scheme of the Act lends numbercountenance to an expedient which may lead to gross evasion of tax.
